Chilli.name: Broad Mites
symptoms: Leaf and Plant Deformation: Leaves become distorted, curled, and thickened, often taking on a finger-like appearance.
New growth is stunted and deformed.
Flower buds and young fruits may drop prematurely.
Discoloration: Leaves develop a bronze or silvery sheen due to cell damage.
Underside of leaves may show brown or reddish spots.
Growth Retardation: Overall plant growth is stunted.
In severe cases, shoot die-back can occur.
Fruit Damage: Fruits develop corky, brown spots and may become deformed.
Fruit quality and yield are significantly reduced.
management: Early detection is crucial for effective management as broad mites multiply rapidly.
Life cycle and behavior of broad mites to understand their spread and timing of control measures.
Favorable conditions for broad mite infestation (e.g., high temperature, humidity).
Prevention strategies such as crop rotation, sanitation, and resistant varieties.
Integrated pest management (IPM) approaches, including biological control options.
Chemical control measures (when necessary) with specific recommendations for chili crops.

Chilli.name: Chili Leaf Curl Virus
symptoms: Curling of the leaves, often becoming wrinkled and puckered.
Reduction of leaf size, veins may become prominent and thickened.
Leaves develop a yellowish or pale green color.
Stunting of plants, resulting in a bushy appearance, internodes are shortened.
Reduced crop yield, fruits may be small, deformed, or fail to develop.
Older leaves become leathery and brittle, and may drop prematurely.
management: Timely management and spraying the crop to control whiteflies.
Uprooting and destruction of the plants prevent the spread of the disease.
Plant chili varieties known to be resistant or tolerant to ChiLCV.
